column2: _PREFATORY NOTE_
column3: underscore PREFATORY NOTE underscore

column2: Dante Gabriel Rossetti, being the son of an Italian who was greatly immersed in the study of Dante Alighieri, and who produced a Comment on the _Inferno_, and other books relating to Dantesque literature, was from his earliest childhood familiar with the name of the stupendous Florentine, and to some extent aware of the range and quality of his writings.
column3: Dante Gabriel Rossetti, being the son of an Italian who was greatly immersed in the study of Dante Alighieri, and who produced a Comment on the underscore Inferno underscore, and other books relating to Dantesque literature, was from his earliest childhood familiar with the name of the stupendous Florentine, and to some extent aware of the range and quality of his writings.

column2: Nevertheless--or perhaps indeed it may have been partly on that very account--he did not in those opening years read Dante to any degree worth mentioning: he was well versed in Shakespeare, Walter Scott, Byron, and some other writers, years before he applied himself to Dante.
column3: Nevertheless-or perhaps indeed it may have been partly on that very account-he did not in those opening years read Dante to any degree worth mentioning: he was well versed in Shakespeare, Walter Scott, Byron, and some other writers, years before he applied himself to Dante.

column2: He may have been fourteen years of age, or even fifteen (May 1843), before he took seriously to the author of the _Divina Commedia_. He then read him eagerly, and with the profoundest admiration and delight; and from the _Commedia_ he proceeded to the lyrical poems and the _Vita Nuova_.
column3: He may have been fourteen years of age, or even fifteen (may eighteen forty three), before he took seriously to the author of the underscore Divina Commedia underscore. column2: I question whether he ever read--unless in the most cursory way--other and less fascinating writings of Alighieri, such as the _Convito_ and the _De Monarchia_.
column3: I question whether he ever read-unless in the most cursory way-other and less fascinating writings of Alighieri, such as the underscore Convito underscore and the underscore De Monarchia underscore.

column2: From reading, Rossetti went on to translating.
column3: From reading, Rossetti went on to translating.

column2: He translated at an early age, chiefly between 1845 and 1849, a great number of poems by the Italians contemporary with Dante, or preceding him; and, among other things, he made a version of the whole _Vita Nuova_, prose and verse.
column3: He translated at an early age, chiefly between eighteen forty five and eighteen forty nine, a great number of poems by the Italians contemporary with Dante, or preceding him; and, among other things, he made a version of the whole underscore Vita Nuova underscore, prose and verse.

column2: This may possibly have been the first important thing that he translated from the Italian: if not the first, still less was it the last, and it may well be that his rendering of the book was completed within the year 1846, or early in 1847.
column3: This may possibly have been the first important thing that he translated from the Italian: if not the first, still less was it the last, and it may well be that his rendering of the book was completed within the year eighteen forty six, or early in eighteen forty seven.

column2: He did not, of course, leave his version exactly as it had come at first: on the contrary, he took counsel with friends (Alfred Tennyson among the number), toned down crudities and juvenilities, and worked to make the whole thing impressive and artistic--for in such matters he was much more chargeable with over-fastidiousness than with laxity.

column2: Still, the work, as we now have it, is essentially the work of those adolescent years--from time to time reconsidered and improved, but not transmuted.
column3: Still, the work, as we now have it, is essentially the work of those adolescent years-from time to time reconsidered and improved, but not transmuted.

column2: Some few years after producing his translation of the _Vita Nuova_, Rossetti was desirous of publishing it, and of illustrating the volume with etchings from various designs, which he had meanwhile done, of incidents in the story.

column2: This project, however, had to be laid aside, owing to want of means, and the etchings were never undertaken.

column2: It was only in 1861 that the volume named _The Early Italian Poets_, including the translated _Vita Nuova_, was brought out: the same volume, with a change in the arrangement of its contents, was reissued in 1874, entitled _Dante and his Circle_.
column3: It was only in eighteen sixty one that the volume named underscore The Early Italian Poets underscore, including the translated underscore Vita Nuova underscore, was brought out: the same volume, with a change in the arrangement of its contents, was reissued in eighteen seventy four, entitled underscore Dante and his Circle underscore.

column2: This book, in its original form, was received with favour, and settled the claim of Rossetti to rank as a poetic translator, or indeed as a poet in his own right.

column2: The life-blood of rhythmical translation is this commandment--that a good poem shall not be turned into a bad one.	The life blood of rhythmical translation is this commandment-that a good poem shall not be turned into a bad one.

column2: The only true motive for putting poetry into a fresh language must be to endow a fresh nation, as far as possible, with one more possession of beauty.
column3: The only true motive for putting poetry into a fresh language must be to endow a fresh nation, as far as possible, with one more possession of beauty.

column2: Poetry not being an exact science, literality of rendering is altogether secondary to this chief law.
column3: Poetry not being an exact science, literality of rendering is altogether secondary to this chief law.

column2: I say _literality_,--not fidelity, which is by no means the same thing.
column3: I say underscore literality underscore,--not fidelity, which is by no means the same thing.

column2: When literality can be combined with what is thus the primary condition of success, the translator is fortunate, and must strive his utmost to unite them; when such object can only be obtained by paraphrase, that is his only path.
column3: When literality can be combined with what is thus the primary condition of success, the translator is fortunate, and must strive his utmost to unite them; when such object can only be obtained by paraphrase, that is his only path.

column2: Any merit possessed by these translations is derived from an effort to follow this principle....

column2: The task of the translator (and with all humility be it spoken) is one of some self-denial.
column3: The task of the translator (and with all humility be it spoken) is one of some self denial.

column2: Often would he avail himself of any special grace of his own idiom and epoch, if only his will belonged to him: often would some cadence serve him but for his author's structure--some structure but for his author's cadence: often the beautiful turn of a stanza must be weakened to adopt some rhyme which will tally, and he sees the poet revelling in abundance of language where himself is scantily supplied. Now he would slight the matter for the music, and now the music for the matter; but no, he must deal to each alike.

column2: When the volume _The Early Italian Poets_ was in preparation, my brother asked me (January 1861) to aid by "collating my _Vita Nuova_ with the original, and amending inaccuracies." He defined the work further as follows: "What I want is that you should correct my translation throughout, removing inaccuracies and mannerisms.

column2: After the departure of this gentlewoman it was the pleasure of the Lord of the Angels to call to His glory a lady young and much of noble[1] aspect, who was very graceful in this aforesaid city: whose body I saw lying without the soul amid many ladies, who were weeping very piteously.	After the departure of this gentlewoman it was the pleasure of the Lord of the Angels to call to His glory a lady young and much of noble[one] aspect, who was very graceful in this aforesaid city: whose body I saw lying without the soul amid many ladies, who were weeping very piteously.
column3: false

column2: Then, remembering that erewhile I had seen her keeping company with that most noble one, I could not withhold some tears. Indeed, weeping, I purposed to speak certain words about her death, in guerdon of my having at some whiles seen her with my lady.
column3: Then, remembering that erewhile I had seen her keeping company with that most noble one, I could not withhold some tears. Indeed, weeping, I purposed to speak certain words about her death, in guerdon of my having at some whiles seen her with my lady.

column2: And somewhat of this I referred to in the last part of the words which I spoke of her, as manifestly appears to him who understands them: and then I composed these two Sonnets--of which the first begins, 'Weep, lovers'--the second, 'Villain Death.'
column3: And somewhat of this I referred to in the last part of the words which I spoke of her, as manifestly appears to him who understands them: and then I composed these two Sonnets-of which the first begins, 'Weep, lovers'--the second, 'Villain Death.'

column2: [1] _Gentile._ The word means "noble" rather than (in its modern shade of meaning) "gentle." "Genteel" would sometimes apply, but has ceased to be admissible in serious writing.

column2: Weep, lovers, since Love weeps,--hearkening what cause makes him wail: Love hears ladies invoking pity, showing bitter grief outwardly by the eyes; because villain Death has set his cruel working upon a noble heart, ruining that which in a noble lady is to be praised in the world, apart from honour. column2: Hear how much Love did her honouring; for I saw him lamenting in very person over the dead seemly image: and often he gazed towards heaven, wherein was already settled the noble soul who had been a lady of such gladsome semblance."

column2: To tax its author with effeminacy on account of the extreme sensitiveness evinced by this narrative of his love, would be manifestly unjust, when we find that, though love alone is the theme of the _Vita Nuova_, war already ranked among its author's experiences at the period to which it relates.

column2: In the year 1289, the one preceding the death of Beatrice, Dante served with the foremost cavalry in the great battle of Campaldino, on the eleventh of June, when the Florentines defeated the people of Arezzo.

column2: In the autumn of the next year, 1290, when for him, by the death of Beatrice, the city as he says "sat solitary," such refuge as he might find from his grief was sought in action and danger: for we learn from the _Commedia_ (Hell, C. xxi.) that he served in the war then waged by Florence upon Pisa, and was present at the surrender of Caprona.
